flashcardSets.title: Business & Economics
flashcardSets.description: Essential academic vocabulary for business, finance, and economic contexts commonly tested in YDS/YÖKDİL

cards.definition: to change frequently in size, amount, quality, etc., especially from one extreme to another
cards.exampleSentence: Currency exchange rates tend to fluctuate based on global economic conditions.

cards.definition: the amount by which money spent or owed is greater than money earned in a particular period of time
cards.exampleSentence: The government is implementing measures to reduce the budget deficit.

cards.definition: an occasion when two or more companies join together to make one larger company
cards.exampleSentence: The merger between the two pharmaceutical companies created a global industry leader.

cards.definition: the process of distributing resources or duties for a particular purpose
cards.exampleSentence: Effective resource allocation is crucial for project success.

cards.definition: the influence or power used to achieve a desired result; to use something to maximum advantage
cards.exampleSentence: Companies can leverage technology to improve their competitive position.

cards.definition: a business project or activity, especially one that involves taking risks
cards.exampleSentence: The company's venture into renewable energy proved highly profitable.

cards.definition: something that encourages a person to do something or to work harder
cards.exampleSentence: The company offers financial incentives to employees who meet their targets.

cards.definition: the principle that a central authority should have a subsidiary function, performing only tasks that cannot be performed at a local level
cards.exampleSentence: The principle of subsidiarity ensures that decisions are made at the most appropriate level.

cards.definition: the amount of business done in a particular period; the rate at which employees leave a company
cards.exampleSentence: The company reported a turnover of $50 million in the last fiscal year.

cards.definition: the state of owning things of value that can easily be exchanged for cash
cards.exampleSentence: Banks must maintain sufficient liquidity to meet customer withdrawals.

cards.definition: to increase the variety of products or investments to reduce risk
cards.exampleSentence: Investors are advised to diversify their portfolios to minimize risk.

cards.definition: a time when business activity or performance is reduced or less successful than before
cards.exampleSentence: The economic downturn resulted in widespread job losses.

cards.definition: a person or group with an interest or concern in something, especially a business
cards.exampleSentence: The company must balance the interests of various stakeholders.

cards.definition: complete control of the supply of particular goods or services, or a company that has such control
cards.exampleSentence: The government broke up the telecommunications monopoly to encourage competition.

cards.definition: a tax or duty to be paid on a particular class of imports or exports
cards.exampleSentence: The government imposed tariffs on imported steel to protect domestic producers.

cards.definition: the process of obtaining goods or services, especially for business purposes
cards.exampleSentence: Effective procurement strategies can significantly reduce operational costs.

cards.definition: to combine several things into a single more effective or coherent whole
cards.exampleSentence: The company plans to consolidate its operations to improve efficiency.

cards.definition: a reduction in the value of an asset over time; a decrease in the value of a currency
cards.exampleSentence: The depreciation of equipment must be accounted for in financial statements.

cards.definition: money paid for work or a service; payment or compensation received for services or employment
cards.exampleSentence: The remuneration package includes salary, bonuses, and benefits.

cards.definition: an official examination of accounts or records; to conduct such an examination
cards.exampleSentence: Independent auditors examine the company's financial statements annually.

cards.definition: to support an organization or activity financially
cards.exampleSentence: The government subsidizes agricultural production to ensure food security.

cards.definition: the use of an arbitrator to settle a dispute
cards.exampleSentence: The parties agreed to settle their commercial dispute through arbitration.

cards.definition: regular and necessary costs, such as rent and heating, that are involved in running a business
cards.exampleSentence: Companies are constantly looking for ways to reduce overhead costs.

cards.definition: property or other assets pledged by a borrower to secure a loan
cards.exampleSentence: The bank requires collateral before approving the business loan.

cards.definition: a standard or point of reference against which things may be compared
cards.exampleSentence: The company's performance is benchmarked against industry standards.

cards.definition: a range of investments held by a person or organization
cards.exampleSentence: A well-balanced investment portfolio reduces overall risk.

cards.definition: something for which a person or company is responsible, especially an amount of money owed; legal responsibility
cards.exampleSentence: The company's liabilities exceeded its assets, leading to bankruptcy.

cards.definition: the value of shares issued by a company; ownership interest in a company
cards.exampleSentence: Shareholders' equity represents the owners' stake in the company.

cards.definition: to obtain goods or services from an outside or foreign supplier
cards.turkishMeaning: dış kaynak kullanmak, dışarıdan tedarik etmek
cards.exampleSentence: Many companies outsource their customer service operations to reduce costs.

cards.definition: a printed document that advertises or describes a business or educational institution
cards.exampleSentence: Investors should carefully read the prospectus before purchasing shares.

flashcardSets.title: Health & Medicine
flashcardSets.description: Critical academic vocabulary for health sciences, medicine, and public health commonly appearing in YDS/YÖKDİL

cards.definition: a bacterium, virus, or other microorganism that can cause disease
cards.exampleSentence: The immune system defends the body against various pathogens.

cards.definition: the likely course or outcome of a disease; a forecast of the likely outcome
cards.exampleSentence: The patient's prognosis improved significantly after early intervention.

cards.definition: the identification of the nature of an illness or other problem by examination of the symptoms
cards.exampleSentence: Early diagnosis of cancer significantly improves survival rates.

cards.definition: persisting for a long time or constantly recurring (of an illness or problem)
cards.exampleSentence: Chronic diseases such as diabetes require long-term management.

cards.definition: regularly found among particular people or in a certain area (of a disease)
cards.exampleSentence: Malaria is endemic in many tropical regions.

cards.definition: a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world
cards.exampleSentence: The COVID-19 pandemic affected healthcare systems worldwide.

cards.definition: the process of making a person or animal immune to infection, typically by vaccination
cards.exampleSentence: Childhood immunization programs have dramatically reduced infectious diseases.

cards.definition: relating to the healing of disease; having a beneficial effect on the body or mind
cards.exampleSentence: The drug has significant therapeutic benefits for cancer patients.

cards.definition: the proportion of a population found to have a condition at a specific time
cards.exampleSentence: The prevalence of obesity has increased dramatically in recent decades.

cards.definition: tending to invade normal tissue or to recur after removal; cancerous
cards.exampleSentence: Malignant tumors require aggressive treatment protocols.

cards.definition: to become progressively worse in quality or condition
cards.exampleSentence: The patient's condition deteriorated rapidly despite intensive care.

cards.definition: likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing; vulnerable to disease
cards.exampleSentence: Elderly individuals are more susceptible to respiratory infections.

cards.definition: capable of being transmitted from one person to another by contact or close proximity
cards.exampleSentence: Influenza is highly contagious and spreads rapidly in crowded environments.

cards.definition: the action of restoring someone to health or normal life through training and therapy
cards.exampleSentence: Physical rehabilitation is essential for stroke recovery.

cards.definition: the state of being subject to death; the number of deaths in a particular population
cards.exampleSentence: Infant mortality rates have declined significantly due to improved healthcare.

cards.definition: a substance with no therapeutic effect used as a control in testing new drugs
cards.exampleSentence: Clinical trials typically compare the drug's effects against a placebo.

cards.definition: a physical or mental feature indicating a condition of disease
cards.exampleSentence: Fever and fatigue are common symptoms of viral infections.

cards.definition: a substance that induces insensitivity to pain; relating to or causing anesthesia
cards.exampleSentence: The surgery was performed under general anesthetic.

cards.definition: the chemical processes that occur within a living organism to maintain life
cards.exampleSentence: Regular exercise can boost your metabolism and aid weight management.

cards.definition: designed to keep something undesirable from occurring; prophylactic
cards.exampleSentence: Preventive medicine focuses on disease prevention rather than treatment.

cards.definition: relating to medicinal drugs; a medicinal drug
cards.exampleSentence: The pharmaceutical industry invests billions in drug development.

cards.definition: preventing success or development; harmful; unfavorable (especially of drug effects)
cards.exampleSentence: The medication was withdrawn due to adverse side effects.

cards.definition: characterized by much sitting and little physical exercise
cards.exampleSentence: A sedentary lifestyle increases the risk of cardiovascular disease.

cards.definition: the presence of unwanted substances or impurities; the action of making something impure
cards.exampleSentence: Water contamination poses serious public health risks.

cards.definition: the capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; the ability to withstand or recover from illness
cards.exampleSentence: Mental resilience is crucial for coping with chronic illness.

cards.definition: relieving pain or symptoms without curing the underlying disease
cards.exampleSentence: Palliative care focuses on improving quality of life for terminally ill patients.

cards.definition: a temporary or permanent decrease or disappearance of signs and symptoms of disease
cards.exampleSentence: The cancer went into remission after chemotherapy.

cards.definition: the period between exposure to an infection and the appearance of symptoms
cards.exampleSentence: The incubation period for influenza is typically one to four days.

cards.definition: the cause or origin of a disease or condition
cards.exampleSentence: Researchers are studying the etiology of autoimmune disorders.

cards.definition: the simultaneous presence of two or more diseases or medical conditions in a patient
cards.exampleSentence: Diabetes and hypertension are common comorbidities in elderly patients.

flashcardSets.title: Environment & Sustainability
flashcardSets.description: Essential academic vocabulary for environmental science, ecology, and sustainability topics in YDS/YÖKDİL

cards.definition: the variety of plant and animal life in a particular habitat or in the world as a whole
cards.exampleSentence: Tropical rainforests contain the highest levels of biodiversity on Earth.

cards.definition: able to be maintained at a certain rate or level; conserving resources to avoid depletion
cards.exampleSentence: Sustainable development balances economic growth with environmental protection.

cards.definition: the action of clearing a wide area of trees
cards.exampleSentence: Deforestation contributes significantly to climate change and habitat loss.

cards.definition: the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of activities
cards.exampleSentence: Individuals can reduce their carbon footprint by using public transportation.

cards.definition: a biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment
cards.exampleSentence: Marine ecosystems are threatened by pollution and overfishing.

cards.definition: capable of being replaced by natural processes; not depleted when used
cards.exampleSentence: Solar and wind power are examples of renewable energy sources.

cards.definition: the protection and preservation of the natural environment and wildlife
cards.exampleSentence: Wildlife conservation efforts have helped save endangered species from extinction.

cards.definition: the presence of harmful or poisonous substances in the environment
cards.exampleSentence: Air pollution in urban areas poses serious health risks.

cards.definition: to make less severe, serious, or painful; to lessen the impact of something harmful
cards.exampleSentence: Countries must take action to mitigate the effects of climate change.

cards.definition: the production and discharge of gases or radiation, especially pollutants
cards.exampleSentence: The government aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030.

cards.definition: reduction in the number or quantity of something; exhaustion of resources
cards.exampleSentence: Ozone layer depletion increases exposure to harmful UV radiation.

cards.definition: the natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism
cards.exampleSentence: Urbanization destroys natural habitats and threatens wildlife populations.

cards.definition: the process by which soil and rock are removed from the Earth's surface by wind or water
cards.exampleSentence: Soil erosion reduces agricultural productivity and increases flooding risks.

cards.definition: a substance used for destroying insects or other organisms harmful to cultivated plants
cards.exampleSentence: Excessive pesticide use can contaminate groundwater and harm beneficial insects.

cards.definition: the state or process of a species, family, or larger group ceasing to exist
cards.exampleSentence: Climate change accelerates the extinction of vulnerable species.

cards.definition: a place to dispose of waste material by burying it and covering it with soil
cards.exampleSentence: Reducing waste sent to landfills is essential for environmental sustainability.

cards.definition: a poisonous substance produced by living organisms; any harmful substance
cards.exampleSentence: Industrial toxins in water supplies pose serious health hazards.

cards.definition: to convert waste into reusable material
cards.exampleSentence: Recycling plastic reduces pollution and conserves natural resources.

cards.definition: the trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's atmosphere by greenhouse gases
cards.exampleSentence: The greenhouse effect is intensified by increased carbon dioxide emissions.

cards.definition: the process by which fertile land becomes desert, typically due to drought or deforestation
cards.exampleSentence: Desertification threatens agricultural lands in arid and semi-arid regions.

cards.definition: the supply of water to land or crops to help growth, typically by means of channels
cards.exampleSentence: Efficient irrigation systems can conserve water while maintaining crop yields.

cards.definition: capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms
cards.exampleSentence: Biodegradable packaging reduces environmental waste.

cards.definition: the capacity of an ecosystem to respond to disturbance and recover from it
cards.exampleSentence: Building ecosystem resilience helps communities adapt to climate change.

cards.definition: an area of land that drains all streams and rainfall to a common outlet
cards.exampleSentence: Protecting watersheds is essential for maintaining clean water supplies.

cards.definition: a body of rock that can store groundwater and transmit it to wells and springs
cards.exampleSentence: Overextraction from aquifers can lead to water scarcity and land subsidence.

cards.definition: decayed organic material used as fertilizer; to make or use compost
cards.exampleSentence: Composting organic waste reduces landfill burden and enriches soil.

cards.definition: the process by which green plants use sunlight to synthesize nutrients from carbon dioxide and water
cards.exampleSentence: Photosynthesis is essential for oxygen production and carbon sequestration.

cards.definition: the action of isolating or hiding something away; carbon storage in natural systems
cards.exampleSentence: Forests play a vital role in carbon sequestration.

cards.definition: excessive richness of nutrients in a body of water, causing dense plant growth
cards.exampleSentence: Eutrophication from agricultural runoff leads to algal blooms and oxygen depletion.

cards.definition: originating from human activity; caused or produced by humans
cards.exampleSentence: Anthropogenic climate change is primarily caused by fossil fuel combustion.

metadata.author: YDS/YÖKDİL Expert System
usageNotes: Each set contains 30 carefully selected academic vocabulary words
Words are chosen based on frequency in YDS/YÖKDİL exams
All entries include pronunciation, definitions, Turkish meanings, example sentences, and collocations
Collocations are essential for YDS/YÖKDİL success - practice them in context
Related forms help build word families for comprehensive vocabulary mastery
Example sentences demonstrate academic register appropriate for exam contexts
